    <item>
      <title>Trump: FBI 'spending too much time' on Russia inquiry and missed Florida shooter signs</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/donald-trump-fbi-russia-inquiry-florida-shooting</link>
      <description><p>The president’s attempt to use the shooting to make a political point about the Russia inquiries drew swift criticism</p><p>Donald Trump has criticized the FBI for missing the “many signals” about the Florida school shooter, saying the agency was spending “too much time” trying to prove Russian collusion with the Trump campaign. <br></p><p>The US president’s attempt to use the shooting to make a political point about the FBI’s Russia inquiries into the Trump campaign drew swift criticism, including from John Kasich, the Republican governor of Ohio, who told CNN it was an “absurd statement”. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/donald-trump-fbi-russia-inquiry-florida-shooting">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>May's Brexit transition demand 'would penalise EU citizens'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/theresa-may-brexit-transition-demand-demonise-eu-citizens-verhofstadt</link>
      <description><p>Unthinkable for EU to agree to PM’s key demand on citizens’ rights, says Verhofstadt</p><p>Theresa May’s demand that EU nationals coming to the UK during a Brexit transition deal should enjoy fewer rights than those already in the country would amount to “penalising citizens”, Guy Verhofstadt has said.</p><p>Verhofstadt, the European parliament’s Brexit coordinator, said May was “not very serious” when she proposed the idea.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/theresa-may-brexit-transition-demand-demonise-eu-citizens-verhofstadt">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Actors and activists join forces on Bafta red carpet to call time on sexism</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/18/actors-activists-bafta-red-carpet-calls-time-sexism</link>
      <description><p>Gemma Arterton, Tessa Thompson, Gemma Chan and Jodie Whittaker are among 190 signatories of letter demanding end to abuse and inequality</p><p>The most famous female stars of British film are set to stand together on Sunday night, each dressed in black, on Bafta’s red carpet outside London’s Royal Albert Hall, many accompanied by feminist activists rather than by their partners.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/sisters-this-is-our-moment-to-say-times-up">Sisters, this is our moment to say Time's Up</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/18/actors-activists-bafta-red-carpet-calls-time-sexism">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Designer label Preen launches collection starting at just 65p</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/designer-label-preen-launches-postage-stamp-collection-starting-65p-duchess-cambrige-finella-dress</link>
      <description><p>Catwalk label’s postage stamp collection features Finella dress worn by Duchess of Cambridge</p><p>Preen, the catwalk label designed by the husband and wife team Justin Thornton and Thea Bregazzi and worn by the Duchess of Cambridge and Gwyneth Paltrow, has launched London fashion week’s most affordable collection, with prices starting at just 65p.</p><p>However, the bargain buys are the size of a postage stamp – literally. A six-stamp collection celebrating 20 years of the brand has been issued by the Isle of Man, where both Thornton and Bregazzi grew up. The first-class stamp features the red Finella dress <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/sep/30/the-duchess-of-cambridge-ambassador-of-british-style-post-brexit">worn by the duchess on a royal tour of Canada</a>. The bodycon “Power Dress” that first made the label famous is honoured on another of the stamps.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/designer-label-preen-launches-postage-stamp-collection-starting-65p-duchess-cambrige-finella-dress">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Met police spy has long-term relationship with activist after quitting covert role</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/18/police-spy-christine-greening-long-term-relationship-activist-tom-frampton-after-quitting-covert-role</link>
      <description><p>Ex-undercover officer Christine Green has been living with campaigner for more than a decade after leaving secret squad</p><p>A police spy quit her undercover deployment and has had a romantic relationship, lasting more than a decade, with one of the prominent political activists she had been sent to monitor. </p><p>The spy, who used the fake identity of Christine Green, met the activist while she spent five years undercover infiltrating the animal rights movement.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/18/police-spy-christine-greening-long-term-relationship-activist-tom-frampton-after-quitting-covert-role">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Israel ready to act against 'dangerous' Iran, Netanyahu warns</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/netanyahu-israel-ready-act-against-dangerous-iran-munich-speech</link>
      <description><p>Tehran will not be allowed to put ‘noose of terror around our neck’, PM says in Munich speech</p><p>Benjamin Netanyahu has said that Israel will act directly against Iran if necessary, not just its allies in the Middle East, reiterating his country’s position that Tehran was the world’s greatest threat.</p><p> As tensions increase in the Middle East over Iran’s role in Syria and Yemen and as Donald Trump presses for a tougher approach on Tehran, Israel is seeking wider support for efforts to contain its regional nemesis.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/netanyahu-israel-ready-act-against-dangerous-iran-munich-speech">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ambulances stuck at A&E 'unable to respond quickly to 999 calls'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/ambulances-stuck-at-ae-unable-to-respond-quickly-to-999-calls</link>
      <description><p>Seriously ill patients having to wait for hours for paramedics to arrive, says NHS boss<br></p><p><br>Patients who have a stroke or heart attack are at “risk of harm” because so many ambulances are stuck at A&amp;E units that they cannot respond quickly enough to 999 calls, an NHS boss is warning.</p><p>The admission, by a senior figure in the NHS ambulance service, has highlighted the growing number of seriously ill patients who are having to wait for several hours – far beyond the target response time of eight minutes – for paramedics to arrive and help them.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/ambulances-stuck-at-ae-unable-to-respond-quickly-to-999-calls">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Brendan Cox resigns from charities amid sexual assault claims</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/brendan-cox-resigns-from-charities-amid-sexual-assault-claims</link>
      <description><p>Husband of murdered MP denies allegations but admits ‘mistakes’ while at Save the Children</p><p>The husband of the murdered MP Jo Cox has resigned from the two charities he set up in her memory after being publicly accused of sexual assault. </p><p>Brendan Cox has stepped down from his posts at <a href="http://www.moreincommon.com/">More in Common</a> and the <a href="https://www.jocoxfoundation.org/">Jo Cox Foundation</a> after allegations, printed in the Mail on Sunday, that he had assaulted a woman in her 30s at Harvard University in 2015. Police filed her complaint as assault and battery but action against him was dropped. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/brendan-cox-resigns-from-charities-amid-sexual-assault-claims">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Iran plane crash in south of country 'kills all 65 onboard'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/iran-plane-crashes-aseman-airlines-yasuj</link>
      <description><p>Aseman Airlines plane crashed en route from Tehran to Yasuj in severe weather conditions, according to state media reports</p><p>All passengers and crew onboard an Iranian commercial flight died after the plane crashed amid severe weather conditions in a mountainous region in the south of the country, state television reported on Sunday. </p><p>Aseman Airlines flight 3705, en route from Tehran to the southern city of Yasuj, the capital of the impoverished province of Kohgiluyeh and Boyer-Ahmad, went off radar 50 minutes into its journey, not far from its destination.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/iran-plane-crashes-aseman-airlines-yasuj">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/iran">Iran</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/plane-crashes">Plane crashes</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/middleeast">Middle East and North Africa</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/world">World news</category>

      <title>Cutting tuition fees would backfire, Justine Greening warns PM</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/18/cutting-tuition-fees-would-backfire-justine-greening-warns-theresa-may</link>
      <description><p>Ex-education secretary says reducing fees for some courses would harm social mobility</p><p>The government’s desire to cut tuition fees for students on courses with lower graduate earnings is fraught with difficulty and unlikely to succeed, the former education secretary Justine Greening has warned.</p><p>Speaking ahead of Theresa May’s announcement on Monday of a major review of higher education funding, Greening outlined her concern that forcing fees lower in such circumstances would backfire and harm social mobility.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/18/cutting-tuition-fees-would-backfire-justine-greening-warns-theresa-may">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Gus Kenworthy's kiss with boyfriend on NBC greeted with acclaim</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/gus-kenworthy-kiss-boyfriend-olympics</link>
      <description><p>The British-born American freestyle skier failed to add to his silver from Sochi, but a historic kiss with his boyfriend on primetime network TV may have made an even bigger impact back home</p><p>When the American freestyle skier Gus Kenworthy shared a kiss with boyfriend Matthew Wilkas at the bottom of the hill before Sunday morning’s ski slopestyle qualifying, neither was immediately aware the moment was captured by NBC’s cameras.</p><p>But the significance of an openly gay male athlete kissing another man on primetime network television during one of the world’s biggest collective experiences was not lost on the Saturday night audience back home in the United States where it quickly went viral and was feted by LGBT activists as a marker of progress amid the <a href="https://www.outsports.com/2018/2/9/16997928/nbc-winter-olympics-lgbt-opening-ceremony">broadcaster’s much-criticized handling</a> of gay athletes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/gus-kenworthy-kiss-boyfriend-olympics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>• OAR confirm ‘possible violation of anti-doping rules’<br />• IOC banned Russia from Pyeongchang over doping<p>A Russian athlete who won a bronze medal in the mixed curling at the Winter Olympics has reportedly failed a drugs test.       <title>Halifax burgeons with new 'Shoreditch of the north' tagline</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/18/halifax-burgeons-with-new-shoreditch-of-the-north-tagline</link>
      <description><p>The West Yorkshire town boasts a flourishing craft beer and music scene, and great pork pies</p><p>Halifax has many claims to fame: the birthplace of a building society, a centre for the Georgian wool trade and, more recently, the setting for a BBC1 drama about childhood sweethearts who have one <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2013/nov/20/last-tango-in-halifax-tv-review">Last Tango</a> in their twilight years.</p><p>Now the West Yorkshire town has gained another tagline. According to BBC 6 Music it is “the Shoreditch of the north”. The station recently <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09p25h8">broadcast live</a> from Halifax, rhapsodising its burgeoning craft beer and music scene and raving about the pork pies at <a href="https://www.facebook.com/thegraystonunity/">the Grayston Unity</a>, the UK’s smallest gig venue - capacity 18, or 12 if the band insists on bringing a drum kit).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/18/halifax-burgeons-with-new-shoreditch-of-the-north-tagline">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cancer, Clare and me: actor Greg Wise on the death of his sister</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/feb/18/actor-greg-wise-not-that-kind-of-love-memoir-blog-sister-clare-interview</link>
      <description><p>A year after the death of his beloved sister, Wise talks about caring for Clare in her last days, and the blog, now a book, they wrote together</p><p>It is more than a year since Clare Wise, sister of the actor Greg Wise, died of cancer. She lived just down the street from the West Hampstead house her brother shares with his wife, Emma Thompson, and their daughter, Gaia. As Greg opens his front door and leads the way into his kitchen, one can see, within minutes, why he was such an indispensable carer to his sister during the last weeks of her life. Today, he has organised elevenses with good coffee and patisserie. As an actor, he is routinely cast as a reprobate (Mountbatten in <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-crown"><em>The Crown</em></a> a debatable exception). In life, he could not be nicer if he tried. And that’s precisely it: he does not appear to be trying – the charm is not fake. When I ask him how he is feeling about Clare’s death now, his eyes fill.</p><p>“I’ve had very few days when I’ve not been actively doing something about Clare, be it probate, sorting out her flat, moving furniture – or just the book.” The book is <em>Not That Kind of Love</em> and is a shared effort, written by Clare and Greg. It is fuelled by wisdom and wisecracks, a story of brotherly, and sisterly, love. Clare was 18 months Greg’s senior (he is 51) and worked for the UK Film Council and as vice president of Universal Pictures. She started a blog in 2013 (although the first lump in her breast was found in 2007) and her take on illness drew a crowd – 96,000 hits (by 2015). No wonder: her style is gallant, funny, self-deprecating. It was not until June 2015 that cancer made its terrible comeback into her bones and Greg moved into her flat to take care of her and Grably (her attention-seeking cat). He also took over the blog when she became too sick to write.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/feb/18/actor-greg-wise-not-that-kind-of-love-memoir-blog-sister-clare-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>I was a pawn in one of the great comedy crimes | Stewart Lee</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/i-was-a-pawn-in-one-of-the-great-comedy-crimes-david-chappelle</link>
      <description><p>David Chappelle claimed he was late onstage because my act had overrun, but perhaps he was constructing an elaborate alibi…</p><p>The weekend before last, my curator friend worried there had been a burglary at his Bloomsbury Museum of Comedy, but nothing was taken. Perhaps some obsessed comedy fan had wanted to caress the stuffed bear from <em>Steptoe and Son</em> with Matthew Corbett’s Sooty puppet while dressed in Freddie Starr’s yellow teddy boy jacket?</p><p>Aware of the impossibility of working out new stuff in front of similarly obsessed fans, especially in the digital surveillance era, the American comedian David Chappelle <a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/how-dave-chappelle-is-creating-844886" title="">seals his audience’s phones in locked bags</a>. I confiscate any I see from the stage and stick them into my anus. But if there were ever more than one a night it would be a squeeze, even for someone with my medical&nbsp;history.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/i-was-a-pawn-in-one-of-the-great-comedy-crimes-david-chappelle">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Selma Blair: 'I'll lose everything, I'll go to court'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global/2018/feb/18/selma-blair-ill-lose-everything-ill-go-to-court-i-will-be-on-the-right-side-of-history-</link>
      <description><p>Selma Blair kept asking herself why she didn’t just hit James Toback and run out of the room. A leading voice in exposing Hollywood talks single parenthood, stray dogs and how speaking out helped her</p><p>Halfway through our interview, Selma Blair’s one-eyed dog Buster climbs on to the restaurant table at the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2011/sep/28/rock-n-roll-hotels-chateau-marmont">Chateau Marmont</a> in LA and happily devours an entire plate of leafy greens. Strangers are staring. I’m staring. “Are you disgusted that I’m letting my dog do this?” Selma asks, her face serious, her tone as drily hilarious as it has been for the past hour, even when discussing the state of Hollywood for women and her fears that she’ll never work again. In fact, I’m just amazed that, here in Hollywood, even rescue mutts with part of their face missing seem to enjoy rocket salad with a blue cheese dressing. “I wonder if it’s possible to overdose on arugula?” she thinks aloud. “We’ll see when the dog dies tonight.”</p><p>Blair made her name with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/dec/18/cruel-intentions-the-musical-le-poisson-rouge-off-broadway"><em>Cruel Intentions</em></a>, a 1999 mean-teen remake of <em>Dangerous Liaisons</em>, and has since acted in <em>Legally Blonde</em>, the <em>Hellboy</em> films directed by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/05/guillermo-del-toro-oscar-frontrunner-dga-award-the-shape-of-water">Guillermo del Toro</a> and in the US remake of <em>Kath &amp; Kim</em>, where she played the hysterically funny and spoiled daughter. More recently she played Kris Jenner in an episode of <em>American Crime Story. </em>Now she’s in a comedy-ish horror film called <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/sep/10/mom-and-dad-review-nicolas-cage-toronto-film-festival-tiff"><em>Mom and Dad</em></a>, which isn’t going down too well in America, what with its theme of parents overtaken by the urge to murder their own children, though Blair’s performance has been praised by the <em>Hollywood Reporter</em>, which describes her as a “<a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/mom-dad-review-1037605">chronically underused talent</a>”. Nicolas Cage plays her husband, and they spend half the movie trying to end their two kids with an assortment of homemade weaponry.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global/2018/feb/18/selma-blair-ill-lose-everything-ill-go-to-court-i-will-be-on-the-right-side-of-history-">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Don’t feed the fatberg! What a slice of oily sewage says about modern life</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/18/dont-feed-fatberg-museum-london-clogging-sewers-oil</link>
      <description><p>A chunk of the monster Whitechapel fatberg is now a superstar museum exhibit. It shines a horrifying light on our throwaway age – but will it stop people clogging up the sewers with the grease from their Sunday lunch?</p><p>The fatberg that went on display this month <a href="https://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/museum-london/event-detail?id=161209">at the Museum of London</a> is proving something of a sensation. Visitor numbers have more than doubled; there is a palpable air of half-term excitement when I visit; and the fatberg fudge – modelled to look like the rough-hewn fatberg brick, with little raisins to represent flies (or something worse) – has sold out. The museum has hit on an unlikely goldmine.</p><p>Unsurprisingly, curator Vyki Sparkes is looking pretty pleased with herself, and is already talking about a world tour for her prized object – a slice of the <a href="http://">giant Whitechapel fatberg discovered last year</a>. There is just one problem: no one knows if it will survive. It is already changing colour as it continues to dry out, and Sparkes is worried that it may start to disintegrate. It is due to be on show at the museum until July. Best come early to avoid disappointment. But, for now, it is an undoubted triumph, raising the question “what is art” – can hardened sewage in a glass case have aesthetic value? – and confronting us with the environmental destructiveness of our throwaway age.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/18/dont-feed-fatberg-museum-london-clogging-sewers-oil">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>It was like the harvest festival and the summer equinox came all at once.       <title>England miss out on T20 tri-series final despite narrow win over New Zealand</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/england-new-zealand-tri-series-twenty20-match-report</link>
      <description>• New Zealand 192-4, England 194-7; England win by two runs<br />• Black Caps seal final against Australia after passing 174 runs<p>A match that summed up England’s disastrous Trans-Tasman tri-series saw victory sealed off the final ball but the game effectively lost 11 deliveries earlier. Needing to beat New Zealand by 20 runs to qualify for the tri-series final, their two-run win, as thrilling as it might have been in any other context, was thoroughly underwhelming. New Zealand will now face Australia in Wednesday’s final at Auckland.</p><p>The team analyst crunched the numbers and after double-checking with the bods at Loughborough overnight, confirmed to Eoin Morgan that victory by around 20 runs – or achieving a target with two or three overs to spare – would see them go through. At the halfway stage, having posted 194 for seven, England had their answer – they needed to keep the Black Caps to 174 or below.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/england-new-zealand-tri-series-twenty20-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The unequal battle: privilege, genes, gender and power | @Anna_Kessel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/the-unequal-battle-privilege-genes-gender-and-power</link>
      <description><p>The tense debate around Caster Semenya and Dutee Chand demonstrate the intersection between race, gender and medical imperialism</p><p>When I was eight years old I visited South Africa, my dad’s homeland, for the first time. I’ll never forget flying into Jo’burg, looking down over the houses in the city and seeing hundreds of turquoise squiggles and dots. “Wow,” I said, excitedly, “everyone has a swimming pool here!”<br></p><p>My dad gave me a stern look. “Not everyone,” he said. It was 1987 and apartheid was in its final throes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/the-unequal-battle-privilege-genes-gender-and-power">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Odds fixed against betters at racecourses, claims bookmaker</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/odds-fixed-against-novice-betters-bookmakers</link>
      <description>• Andy Smith says fellow bookmakers target inovice gamblers<br />• Ffos Las in Wales last August offered notably poor odds<p>Racecourse bookmakers collude to rip-off punters, according to a sensational claim by one of their number this week. Andy Smith, who takes bets as ‘Festival Racing’ and is known for his outspoken views, said bookies sometimes agree before racing starts they will build a particularly big profit margin into their odds, especially when a large crowd of inexperienced gamblers is expected.</p><p>Smith’s comments were prompted by a survey published recently <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/waiting-patiently-cue-card-ascot-chase-ruth-jefferson-colin-tizzard" title="">by the Horseracing Bettors</a> Forum, which showed odds offered at the Welsh racetrack Ffos Las were notably poor last year, most obviously on 25 August. That was the fixture marketed as ‘Ladies’ Day’, when the track had its biggest attendance of the year, at around 6,000 people.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/odds-fixed-against-novice-betters-bookmakers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is there any hope for truth? I went to a conference to find out | Rhik Samadder</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/is-there-any-hope-for-truth-i-went-to-a-conference-to-find-out</link>
      <description><p>From bot factories weaponising misinformation to Twitter trolls polluting online debate, we are all living in a fake news world – unless, it turns out, you are a teen</p><p>Have we destroyed truth? How can we live in a fake news world? When will The Experts Strike Back? To find out, I blagged my way into an academic event, looking for answers. <a href="https://www.knowledgequarter.london/kq-conference-2018/future-of-knowledge-2018/">The Future of Knowledge</a> was hosted by Knowledge Quarter, an assembly of organisations in the King’s Cross area that includes Soas, the British Library, the British Museum and the Institute of Physics – a bit like <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2011/sep/22/your-next-box-set-avengers">The Avengers</a>.</p><p>On one of the panels was historian and film-maker <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/david-olusoga">David Olusoga</a>, the smartest, most miserable man I have ever heard speak. “The historian Oswald Spengler said that optimism is cowardice,” he began. He went on to draw parallels between now and the 1920s, both being characterised by a flight from reason and the rise of propaganda. Our age is different, he said, because it is worse. He is right. Social media – anonymous, empowering and narcissistic – has polluted our debates. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/02/putin-kremlin-inside-russian-troll-house">Bot factories in Russia have weaponised misinformation</a>, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/03/donald-trump-boasts-nuclear-button-bigger-kim-jong-un">Trump edges us closer to nuclear extinction with a tweet</a>, yet after a hard weekend hitting the Häagen-Dazs I can’t post a picture of my nipples on Instagram? I have lost track of what I was saying. That is another thing: <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/05/crimes-of-attention-stalkers-killers-jihadists-longing">we all have shorter attention spans</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/is-there-any-hope-for-truth-i-went-to-a-conference-to-find-out">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>It’s completely horrible and potentially deadly – but at least it’s got us talking to each other</p><p>It goes spring, summer, autumn, winter, flu. This is a season of sickness, and the only season yet to be immortalised in a poem. There are no hedges and buttercups here, only the creeping mountain of toilet paper, scrunched, the smells are not those of lilacs, instead the ripe breath of someone with some terrible memory in their throat.</p><p>Flu is walking among us, poking us with its poisoned umbrellas</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/flu-is-uniting-the-country-in-an-orgy-of-spluttering-misery">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>If paying for sex is wrong in Haiti, why do we still tolerate it in the UK? | Catherine Bennett</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/if-paying-for-sex-wrong-in-haiti-why-do-we-tolerate-it-in-uk</link>
      <description>Amid anger at Oxfam, where are the voices of those who turn a blind eye to exploited  women at home?<p>Finally, something on which we can agree: charity officials ought not to buy sex. No one, so far, seems prominently to have argued, of the Oxfam employees’ misconduct in Haiti and Liberia, that, providing their female purchases were adult, and not coerced, then their prostitution should rightly be called sex work, that is: a perfectly dignified transaction, from which both sides – say, impoverished survivors of a disaster and benevolent male humanitarians – stood to benefit.</p><p>We have yet, admittedly, to hear from Amnesty International, the human rights NGO, which now doubles as the world’s leading advocate of legalised prostitution. In 2015, a year that will forever be celebrated by its allies in the pimping and trafficking community, Amnesty committed to the decriminalisation of all aspects of “sex work that does not involve coercion, exploitation or abuse”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/if-paying-for-sex-wrong-in-haiti-why-do-we-tolerate-it-in-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>How can we regulate our savage market for instant news?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/media-blog/2018/feb/18/how-can-we-regulate-our-savage-market-for-instant-news</link>
      <description><p>Without consensus on how to cover events such as the Florida massacre, publishers are stuck</p><p>Bullet holes in a computer screen, filmed by a cowering high school student sheltering in a classroom where a gunman was on the loose: just one of the images in the visual market created for those watching the news of the shooting at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas high school in Florida. A map on the social messaging app Snapchat displayed pictures and videos located at the school as the shooting took place. Grabbed and recycled from mobile phone screens, they circulated through television channels, radio and websites almost instantaneously.</p><p>Much of what we know about the shooting, both in terms of how the events unfolded and what led up to them, was learned through social media channels. The perpetrator, Nikolas Cruz, a 19-year-old recent graduate of the school, had seemingly been flagging his disturbing interest in mass killing for some time through Instagram posts and even a comment on a YouTube video about becoming “a professional high school shooter”. Last week the FBI admitted it had <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/florida-shooting-fbi-nikolas-cruz">failed to investigate a tipoff in January</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/media-blog/2018/feb/18/how-can-we-regulate-our-savage-market-for-instant-news">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>You’ve heard about the north-south divide. How about the west-east one? | Will Hutton</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/youve-heard-about-north-south-divide-how-about-west-east-one</link>
      <description>Geographical inequalities are the result of historical legacies and a fractured economy<p>Place has always been destiny in Britain, but never more so than in 2018. Pity the child born in Weymouth, Corby or Carlisle, locked into poor schools, a lacklustre economy and few decent jobs; if he or she had been lucky enough to be born in Tower Hamlets, Hackney or Westminster, their <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/2017/nov/28/social-mobility-stark-postcode-lottery-too-many-britain-left-behind-alan-milburn-commission-report" title="">life chances</a> might have been transformed. Where you are born in Britain, and England in particular, is becoming ever more a treacherous geographical lottery.</p><p>Nor is the divide any more just the well-known one between north and south. So relatively strong are the performances of Bristol and Manchester, with Liverpool hard on their heels, that overlaid on the old north-south split is the beginnings of a new one – an east-west divide. Parts of the north-west such as Trafford and North Cheshire are strong economic and social performers, while the towns along the M4 and Bristol itself are doing pretty well.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/youve-heard-about-north-south-divide-how-about-west-east-one">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>The Girls creator deserves compassion, not condemnation, for her decision to have a hysterectomy<p>Only the hardest of hearts would not feel sympathy for <em>Girls</em> creator, Lena Dunham, right now. She’s <a href="https://www.vogue.com/article/lena-dunham-hysterectomy-vogue-march-2018-issue" title="">written – extremely eloquently – in <em>Vogue</em></a> about how, after many years suffering from crippling endometriosis, she elected to have a hysterectomy.</p><p>My first reaction was shock – Dunham is a young woman: did she really have to do something so final? (She writes in the article about her sadness about not being able to carry a child.) In other coverage, experts (and the not-so-expert) expressed consternation – it wasn’t even certain that the hysterectomy would eliminate all the problems.       <title>Barry Bennell: unmasking of football paedophile who ruined young lives – video explainer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2018/feb/15/barry-bennell-a-football-scandal-video</link>
      <description><p>For 25 years Barry Bennell lived a dual existence, publicly he was lauded as one of English football's best talent spotters but in private he committed a campaign of sexual abuse against the young boys in his care. When Andy Woodward, one of Bennell's victims, eschewed his anonymity in an interview with Daniel Taylor, the story instigated the largest ever police investigation into sexual abuse in the UK.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/barry-bennell-abuse-manchester-city-crewe">The predatory Pied Piper who made stars and shattered lives</a></p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/manchester-city-barry-bennell-warning">Manchester City ‘ignored warnings’ and kept Barry Bennell in youth set-up</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2018/feb/15/barry-bennell-a-football-scandal-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>I'm a Dreamer: here is what's happening – video explainer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2018/feb/08/im-a-dreamer-video-explainer</link>
      <description><p>Justino Mora is a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/27/dreamers-reform-democrats-shutdown">Dreamer</a> who arrived in the US aged 11 as an undocumented immigrant. Growing up undocumented meant constantly living in fear of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/06/us-mexico-border-migrant-deaths-rose-2017">deportation</a>, until Barack Obama introduced Daca in 2012, which protected Dreamers. 
But in September 2017, the Trump administration undid the Daca system, throwing the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/08/nancy-pelosi-gives-record-eight-hour-speech-on-dreamers">future</a> of dreamers into question&nbsp;</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2018/feb/08/im-a-dreamer-video-explainer">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Jamie Nicholls and Katie Summerhayes have something in common beyond making Team GB for Pyeongchang 2018, they grew up on the dry ski slopes across Yorkshire. Aside from providing a further two athletes for the 2018 ski team, the Yorkshire scene has produced a slew of World Cup medals.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2018/feb/07/fearless-five-years-after-delhi-gang-rape-has-anything-changed-for-women-in-india-video</link>
      <description><p>The brutal rape of a 23-year-old student on a bus in Delhi shocked the world. The victim, who became known as Nirbhaya (‘fearless’), succumbed to her injuries two weeks later, but not before giving testimonies against her attackers. Her death provoked outrage and protests across India as people demanded dramatic improvements to women’s rights. But five years on, has anything really changed?     <item>
      <title>Sofia Coppola on the film that launched her – The Start podcast</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/audio/2018/jan/25/the-start-podcast-sofia-coppola-virgin-suicides</link>
      <description><p>Our new culture podcast, The Start, brings major artists to the mic to reveal how they began their careers. In this first episode, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/sofia-coppola">Sofia Coppola</a> talks about the fear and the thrill of directing her debut film, The Virgin Suicides</p><p><strong>Subscribe and review on <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/id1337773497">Apple Podcasts</a> or <a href="https://www.acast.com/thestart">Acast</a>, and join the discussion on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/GuardianPodcasts/">Facebook</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/guardianaudio">Twitter</a></strong></p><p>At the 1999 Cannes film festival, attendees watched the work of a little-known 28 year old. That film was The Virgin Suicides, written, directed, and produced by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/jan/25/sofia-coppola-on-the-virgin-suicides-director-debut">Sofia Coppola</a>. The novel by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/jeffrey-eugenides">Jeffrey Eugenides</a> about a doomed family of teenage sisters had resonated so much with the young Sofia she felt compelled to step behind the camera and make her own mark on movies.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/audio/2018/jan/25/the-start-podcast-sofia-coppola-virgin-suicides">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Rokhaya Diallo is a French journalist and activist who was appointed to the CNNum, the national digital council at the end of last year.       <title>Peter Bradshaw's predictions for the 2018 film Baftas</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2018/feb/18/film-baftas-peter-bradshaw-predictions-2018-death-stalin-lady-macbeth</link>
      <description><p>Will Brit hopefuls Lady Macbeth and The Death of Stalin triumph? And will Daniel Day-Lewis get a final gong before retiring? Our chief critic places his bets</p><p>The Baftas are almost here, exciting news for the truly excellent British films which could well be rewarded: Lady Macbeth, The Death of Stalin, God’s Own Country. There could well be a final Bafta for one of Britain’s great screen actors, Daniel Day-Lewis (although he has dual citizenship with the Republic of Ireland) who is bowing out with a sensational performance, in fact one of his very best, as the enigmatic 1950s fashion designer Reynolds Woodcock in Paul Thomas Anderson’s Phantom Thread. My guess is that Guillermo Del Toro’s swooning romance The Shape of Water will be the big winner, but that Greta Gerwig’s tremendous autobiographical coming-of-age comedy Lady Bird will have a real showing, largely because of a possible win for Saoirse Ronan in the lead. It is a real disappointment that Bafta voters could not find it in their collective hearts to include a female director on the nomination list. This could have gone, in my view to Gerwig, or to Dee Rees for Mudbound, or even to the brilliantly talented Anna Biller for her The Love Witch. Anyway, here are my predictions:</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2018/feb/18/film-baftas-peter-bradshaw-predictions-2018-death-stalin-lady-macbeth">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Daniela Vega: the transgender star lighting up the film industry</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/18/daniela-vega-transgender-star-film-industry-a-fantastic-woman-interview</link>
      <description>Following her breakthrough role in Oscar-nominated Chilean film A Fantastic Woman, the actor talks about finding her voice, her diva grandmother, and winding up conservatives<p>You have to be one hell of a performer to take the title role in a film called <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/feb/14/a-fantastic-woman-review-sebastian-lelio-daniela-vega"><em>A Fantastic Woman</em></a> and convince the world that, yes, your character truly is a fantastic woman and you are too. And if you’re a largely unknown actor in only your second movie, it takes some quite remarkable self-assurance. But, a decade after transitioning as female, and a year after her breakthrough role dazzled the Berlin film festival, Chilean newcomer Daniela Vega is fully enjoying the rewards of being fantastic and on her own terms. She didn’t model her character in the film on any screen stars, she says, and the same goes for discovering her own identity as a woman. “Soy muy yo,” she says – “I’m very much me.”</p><p>Directed by Sebastián Lelio , <em>A Fantastic Woman</em>, the follow-up to his acclaimed female-centred drama <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/oct/31/gloria-review"><em>Gloria, </em></a><em> </em>has been the toast of the festival circuit over the past year and is now heading for the Academy Awards, where it’s up for best foreign language film. It’s a magnificent work, stylish, playful and highly serious and, despite its protagonist’s sometimes harrowing ordeals, exuberantly uplifting. But what seals the film’s brilliance is Vega’s extraordinary portrayal of Marina, a young trans woman facing intense social hostility. It may be that, as Juliet Jacques suggested in a<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/02/juliet-jacques-hollywood-transgender-fantastic-woman"> recent <em>Guardian</em> article</a>, that in playing someone whose experience is in some ways close to hers, a trans actor such as Vega is able to bring a special bonus of “emotional memory” to her performance. But regardless of the viewer’s curiosity as to whether or not Vega essentially “is” Marina, there’s no denying that she brings a depth, sophistication and resilience to the role. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/18/daniela-vega-transgender-star-film-industry-a-fantastic-woman-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Will Young: ‘Our podcast is a queer Woman's Hour’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/will-young-our-podcast-is-a-queer-womans-hour-homo-sapiens</link>
      <description><p>Homo Sapiens is a frank and funny podcast hosted by Will Young and film director Chris Sweeney. Mark Smith joins them on tour in the north of England</p><p>Will Young hasn’t been to a sexual health clinic before so our hosts at Manchester’s <a href="http://lgbt.foundation/">LGBT Foundation</a>, a community charity near the city’s gay village, are keen to impress upon him that sandwiches and cakes do not come as standard for its service users. “They’re posh ones from the deli – not the Greggs stuff we usually lay on for visitors,” remarks Peter Brampton, a sparky sexual health project leader.</p><p>Young and his film director friend Chris Sweeney are here as part of their tour of the north of England for the second season of their rose-tinted yet highly successful podcast <a href="http://homosapienspodcast.com/"><em>Homo Sapiens</em></a>. The first series heard the pair chatting to LGBTQ+ luminaries, such as the trans actor <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/aug/22/rebecca-root-interview-not-fighting-myself-any-more">Rebecca Root</a>, actor <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/bisi-alimi">Bisi Alimi</a> (who caused fury in his native Nigeria by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2016/feb/09/bisi-alimi-on-lgbt-rights-in-nigeria-it-may-take-60-years-but-we-have-to-start-now">coming out</a> on television) and human rights activist <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/petertatchell">Peter Tatchell</a>. A visit to his tiny London flat was poignant, with Young somehow managing to convey the depths of Tatchell’s personal sacrifice with fretful asides about the dusty clutter.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/will-young-our-podcast-is-a-queer-womans-hour-homo-sapiens">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Shape of Water review – a seductively melancholy creature feature</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/18/the-shape-of-water-review-guillermo-del-toro-sally-hawkins</link>
      <description><p>Guillermo del Toro’s magical movie, a cold war thriller, is underpinned by a superb cast and knowing nods to Hollywood classics</p><p>In my opinion, the 21st century has produced no finer movie than <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2006/nov/05/features.review1"><em>Pan’s Labyrinth</em></a>, Guillermo del Toro’s 2006 masterpiece, which acts as a sister picture to his 2001 Spanish civil war ghost story, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/News_Story/Critic_Review/Observer_review/0,,610241,00.html"><em>The Devil’s Backbone</em></a>. Like Del Toro’s first feature, <em>Cronos</em> (1993), these Spanish-language gems possessed a unique cinematic voice, the distant echo of which could still be heard even amid the thunderous roar of 2013’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/jul/14/pacific-rim-review-philip-french"><em>Pacific Rim</em></a>. Now, with his awards-garlanded latest (co-scripted by <em>Game of Thrones</em> graduate Vanessa Taylor), Del Toro has conjured a boundary-crossing hybrid that is as adventurously personal as it is universal, a swooning romantic melodrama that reshapes the mythical themes of Beauty and the Beast with deliciously bestial bite.</p><p>An opening voiceover establishes the fable-like tone, setting the story “a long time ago” in “a small city near the coast, but far from everything else”. This is the US in the early-60s, with the cold war and the space race providing the backdrop for “a tale of love and loss and the monster who tried to destroy it all”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/18/the-shape-of-water-review-guillermo-del-toro-sally-hawkins">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Morrissey review – aloof, obnoxious and proudly provocative</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/morrissey-review-hydro-glasgow</link>
      <description><p><strong>Hydro, Glasgow<br></strong>For someone who often seems determined to alienate his fanbase, Morrissey has a knack for intuiting exactly what they want</p><p>If all publicity really is good publicity then <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/nov/16/morrissey-low-in-high-school-review-old-greatness-spoiled-by-ugliness-and-spite">Morrissey’s Low in High School </a>campaign should be judged a tremendous success. While promoting his 11th solo album he zoomed off-piste during a BBC 6 Music session to float conspiracy theories about the <a href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/events/evfwhn/live/cwz5d4">Ukip leadership election</a> and engaged in a tetchy war of words with a German newspaper that published an interview in which he appeared to defend <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-42338456">Kevin Spacey</a>. Alongside these self-sabotaging lows, there have also been some highs. Los Angeles, the stronghold of his ardent US fanbase, declared 10 November to be <a href="http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-morrissey-hollywood-bowl-review-20171111-story.html]">Morrissey Day in his honour</a>.</p><p>For those still loyal to the Smiths godhead, like the sizeable crowd in this Glasgow arena, dealing with a certain amount of aloof obnoxiousness simply seems par for the course. Even some of the rolling videos that serve as preamble to this gig feel like trolling. Alongside clips of the New York Dolls, Germaine Greer and the Four Tops, there is extended footage of Russian pop duo Tatu performing their shrill cover of How Soon is Now? on Top of the Pops in 2003.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/morrissey-review-hydro-glasgow">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I'm With Her: ‘We’re about camaraderie, not Hillary’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/im-with-her-band-interview-bluegrass-music-aoife-odonovan-sara-watkins-sarah-jarosz</link>
      <description><p>Women are expected to take a back seat in the arch-conservative world of bluegrass music. But Aoife O’Donovan, Sara Watkins and Sarah Jarosz refused to be sidelined – even after Hillary Clinton ‘borrowed’ their band name</p><p><a href="https://www.imwithherband.com/">I’m With Her</a> had been playing together for 18 months when <a href="https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CZscPjmWIAIHVy4.jpg">Hillary Clinton unwittingly commandeered their band name</a>. “It wasn’t the worst thing in the world,” says Aoife O’Donovan. “If that campaign slogan had been on the other side, we might have rethought the situation.”</p><p>Then again, a band called Make America Great Again would probably do well in the archly conservative bluegrass world that these women frequent. The Hillary connection, not so much. “I’m sure it’ll be a turn-off for some people,” says <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/jan/30/sara-watkins-fiddle-interview">Sara Watkins</a>, the other member of the trio alongside <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/jan/30/aoife-odonovan-dingwalls-review">O’Donovan</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jun/19/sarah-jarosz-undercurrent-review-classy-americana">Sarah Jarosz</a>. “But that’s not what the band is about – we’re not making a political statement. It’s a celebration of each other. It’s camaraderie.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/im-with-her-band-interview-bluegrass-music-aoife-odonovan-sara-watkins-sarah-jarosz">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Ai Weiwei on the project that awoke his political voice – The Start podcast</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/audio/2018/feb/15/ai-weiwei-on-project-political-voice-sichuan-earthquake-the-start-podcast</link>
      <description><p>The artist and activist tells how investigating schoolchildren’s deaths in the Sichuan earthquake of 2008 spawned his mammoth installation, Remembering</p><p><strong>Subscribe and review on <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/id1337773497">Apple Podcasts</a> or <a href="https://www.acast.com/thestart">Acast</a>, and join the discussion on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/GuardianPodcasts/">Facebook</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/guardianaudio">Twitter</a></strong></p><p>In 2008, an earthquake devastated Sichuan province in China, claiming the lives of more than 69,000 people. Following accusations from parents that substandard construction caused the collapse of schools across in the region, the artist <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/ai-weiwei">Ai Weiwei</a> set upon a political investigation that would name every missing student and call the government to account for their deaths.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/audio/2018/feb/15/ai-weiwei-on-project-political-voice-sichuan-earthquake-the-start-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Who do you trust more with your money – your partner or your bank?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/the-relationship-project/2018/feb/14/who-do-you-trust-more-with-your-money-your-partner-or-your-bank</link>
      <description><p>Arguing over how to handle the finances is a common source of relationship tension, but new research reveals we’re far more likely to trust our partners with our money than our banks </p><p> Few long-term relationships are without their money quarrels, whether it’s deciding whose turn it is to pay for the weekly supermarket shop, or if it’s acceptable to use the joint bank account for a round of drinks for your workmates. But, despite this, it seems we’d sooner trust our partner with our finances than our banks.</p><p>A recent survey for the Guardian and TSB by Ipsos Mori reveals that 52% of adults who are currently in a relationship said they’d trust their partner with their money over their banks. Only 16% of adults who were in a relationship said they’d trust their banks more with their money.<br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/the-relationship-project/2018/feb/14/who-do-you-trust-more-with-your-money-your-partner-or-your-bank">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Quiz: How secure are you online?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cyber-aware/2018/feb/14/quiz-how-secure-are-you-online</link>
      <description><p>Take this quiz to see how secure your online habits are – and what you can do to improve them</p><p>These days, we’re almost always connected. From socialising to doing the weekly shop, almost everything can be done online. But how often do you stop to think about how much you’re sharing data and whether you’re inviting someone to take advantage of your digital life? Take this quick quiz to find out.</p><p class="question__text">How do you manage your passwords for multiple online accounts?</p><p class="answer__text">I cycle through a few different common passwords</p><p class="answer__text">I use different passwords for all my accounts and keep them written down</p><p class="answer__text">I use the same password for almost all accounts</p><p class="answer__text">I have a strong, separate password for my main email account</p><p class="question__text">Do you use two-factor (or multi-factor) authentication for everything?</p><p class="answer__text">Only when it’s forced upon me, like with my online banking</p><p class="answer__text">I’ve never even heard of it</p><p class="answer__text">Yes, I use it for everything where possible</p><p class="answer__text">I’ve heard it’s more secure, but I haven’t started using it yet</p><p class="question__text">Are your social media accounts public?</p><p class="answer__text">No, I keep them all private and always vet who I become friends with </p><p class="answer__text">No, they are private but I accept anyone’s friend or follow requests</p><p class="answer__text">Yes, they are all public</p><p class="answer__text">Some of my accounts are private and some are public</p><p class="question__text">Have you ever included any of the following information in a CV you uploaded online? National insurance number, date of birth, full address?</p><p class="answer__text">Yes, I include it on every CV I submit online</p><p class="answer__text">I have only included some of that information on CVs uploaded online</p><p class="answer__text">I never upload a CV online with private information like that</p><p class="answer__text">I send CVs by email with that information, without checking if the company is legitimate or not</p><p class="question__text">How much attention do you pay to the privacy information when you download a new app to see how much access you are granting?</p><p class="answer__text">No, I never read through the long privacy information descriptions</p><p class="answer__text">I usually check the details, unless a friend has recommended it</p><p class="answer__text">I skim read the information</p><p class="answer__text">I try to read all the information and regularly check my phone settings to see how much permission I am giving each app </p><p class="question__text">Are your passwords:</p><p class="answer__text">Three random words with numbers and symbols</p><p class="answer__text">Memorable words with numbers and symbols added on</p><p class="answer__text">Simple and easy to remember, like ‘password123’</p><p class="answer__text">Related to my personal information that nobody would really know about me</p><p class="question__text">If you were contacted by a potential employer online, would you:</p><p class="answer__text">Give them your name, address, national insurance number and date of birth</p><p class="answer__text">Give them any information they ask for, even bank details</p><p class="answer__text">Not give away any sensitive information, for example national insurance number, until after an interview or offer and when you know they are a legitimate employer</p><p class="answer__text">Try your best to check they are legitimate, but give them some information such as your address and date of birth before you had an interview</p><p class="question__text">Do you always install the latest software and app updates when they become available?</p><p class="answer__text">I wait a few weeks but do install them eventually</p><p class="answer__text">I install them all as soon as possible</p><p class="answer__text">I never update my software</p><p class="answer__text">I only update the apps I love</p><p class="question__text">Do you connect to public wifi when out and about?</p><p class="answer__text">Sure, what’s the problem?</p><p class="answer__text">Yes, I use public wifi for everything I do online</p><p class="answer__text">No, never</p><p class="answer__text">I only use public wifi for the internet and emails, but never for transferring sensitive information</p><p class="question__text">Do you regularly review your social media settings?</p><p class="answer__text">No, I’ve never checked them</p><p class="answer__text">Yes, I check the settings regularly or each time there is an update to a social media app</p><p class="answer__text">I check the settings about once a year</p><p class="answer__text">I configured them when I first set up the accounts, but haven’t looked again since</p><p class="score__min-score">12 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Excellent. Congratulations, your online behaviour is very secure. Nothing is getting past you! Stay wary though and don’t get complacent. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website (cyberaware.gov.uk).</p><p class="score__min-score">11 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Excellent. Congratulations, your online behaviour is very secure. Nothing is getting past you! Stay wary though and don’t get complacent. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website (cyberaware.gov.uk).</p><p class="score__min-score">10 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Excellent. Congratulations, your online behaviour is very secure. Nothing is getting past you! Stay wary though and don’t get complacent. To stay up to date with the latest cyber security advice visit Cyber Aware.</p><p class="score__min-score">9 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Excellent. Congratulations, your online behaviour is very secure. Nothing is getting past you! Stay wary though and don’t get complacent. To stay up to date with the latest cyber security advice visit Cyber Aware.</p><p class="score__min-score">8 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Good. You take online security very seriously and you make it almost as difficult as possible for a hacker to steal your private data. Make sure to keep up the good work – and, for the questions you did get wrong, have a think about how you can improve. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website.</p><p class="score__min-score">7 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Good. You take online security very seriously and you make it almost as difficult as possible for a hacker to steal your private data. Make sure to keep up the good work – and, for the questions you did get wrong, have a think about how you can improve. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website.</p><p class="score__min-score">6 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Room for improvement. You have a basic understanding of security online but perhaps don’t take it too seriously. If you want to make sure you are not a target, take some simple steps to up your game. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website.</p><p class="score__min-score">5 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Room for improvement. You have a basic understanding of security online but perhaps don’t take it too seriously. If you want to make sure you are not a target, take some simple steps to up your game. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website.</p><p class="score__min-score">4 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Room for improvement. You have a basic understanding of security online but perhaps don’t take it too seriously. If you want to make sure you are not a target, take some simple steps to up your game. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website.</p><p class="score__min-score">3 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Poor. You are a cyber criminal’s dream! Make sure you take steps to learn more about cybersecurity, be careful about the information you share online and always check to see if apps are asking for access to your location or microphone – they could be monitoring your every move. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website.</p><p class="score__min-score">2 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Poor. You are a cyber criminal’s dream! Make sure you take steps to learn more about cybersecurity, be careful about the information you share online and always check to see if apps are asking for access to your location or microphone – they could be monitoring your every move. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website.</p><p class="score__min-score">0 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Poor. You are a cyber criminal’s dream! Make sure you take steps to learn more about cybersecurity, be careful about the information you share online and always check to see if apps are asking for access to your location or microphone – they could be monitoring your every move. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website.</p><p class="score__min-score">1 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Poor. You are a cyber criminal’s dream! Make sure you take steps to learn more about cybersecurity, be careful about the information you share online and always check to see if apps are asking for access to your location or microphone – they could be monitoring your every move. For tips on how to stay secure online, visit the Cyber Aware website.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cyber-aware/2018/feb/14/quiz-how-secure-are-you-online">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Seven architectural wonders of Abu Dhabi</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/discover-abu-dhabi/2018/feb/15/seven-architectural-wonders-abu-dhabi</link>
      <description><p>Futuristic designs are transforming the UAE capital’s skyline, in the shape of Aldar HQ, the Sheikh Zayed Bridge and the leaning tower of Capital Gate. David Clack is dazzled by the structures<br></p><p>With world-class architects lining up to make their mark on the city, Abu Dhabi’s skyline is transforming into one of the most exciting on Earth. Ancient tradition means it’s big on eclecticism, too – where else would you find a giant marble mosque sat cheek-by-jowl with a wonky skyscraper? Here’s where to make a beeline for in the UAE capital.</p><p><strong>Louvre Abu Dhabi</strong><br>Given the calibre of the art within, <a href="https://www.louvreabudhabi.ae/" rel="nofollow">Louvre Abu Dhabi</a> could just as easily have been a grey, featureless box and still draw the crowds. Instead, the intricate, perforated dome designed by Jean Nouvel (Barcelona’s Torre Glòries’ architect) comes very close to upstaging the staggering selection of paintings and objects beneath it. Stunning as it is from afar, it’s not until you step inside that you get to witness the building’s neatest trick: the spectacular light show cast across the museum’s hallways as the criss-crossing canopy meets the near-constant Arabian sun.<br><strong><em><br>Don’t miss</em> </strong><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/dec/07/world-record-da-vinci-painting-to-be-exhibited-at-louvre-abu-dhabi">Da Vinci’s record-obliterating Salvator Mundi</a> is heading to the museum. Expect Mona Lisa-level hysteria.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/discover-abu-dhabi/2018/feb/15/seven-architectural-wonders-abu-dhabi">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Explore it with a local: Leeuwarden, the Netherlands’ capital of culture</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/18/leeuwarden-the-netherlands-european-capital-of-culture-with-a-local</link>
      <description><p>The best way to see this year’s joint European Capital of Culture is to ask the residents to show you their city – for free</p><p>It’s just after 10am and I’m cycling through the narrow cobblestone streets of Leeuwarden in the Netherlands, past canals with ivy-covered banks and perfectly preserved 17th-century merchant houses, thanks to Mila and her boyfriend Wilmar, our guides for the day. “Bike is by far the best way to see the city,” says Mila. “The only rule is you’ve got to bring us back afterwards. And in the same condition.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/18/leeuwarden-the-netherlands-european-capital-of-culture-with-a-local">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>My husband died and my son is angry I’m in a new relationship | Dear Mariella</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/my-husband-died-and-my-son-is-angry-i-am-in-a-new-relationship-mariella-frostrup</link>
      <description><p>Mothers and sons is the greatest love story never told, says Mariella Frostrup. Stay patient but don’t stop seeing your new lover</p><p><strong><em>The dilemma</em></strong><em> My husband died suddenly early last year. It has been tough for me and for my teen/20s children. We’ve worked hard to support our grief and have been close. They have lovely friends and special loves who have been wonderful and supportive – and they are OK, me too.</em></p><p><em>I have become close to someone I have known vaguely for 10 years. He is lovely and we seem to have embarked on something special. In our 50s neither of us want to fanny about and he seems willing to accept the baggage I carry (and he has some, too).&nbsp;I feel the same. </em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/my-husband-died-and-my-son-is-angry-i-am-in-a-new-relationship-mariella-frostrup">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Nuala, London: ‘Some beautiful moments’ – restaurant review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/nuala-london-some-beautiful-moments-restaurant-review</link>
      <description><p>If Nuala were a racehorse, it would have a fine pedigree, and get off to a flying start. But then the going gets hard</p><p><strong>Nuala, 70-74 City Road, London EC1Y 2BJ (020 3904 0462). Meal for two, including drinks and service, £120</strong></p><p>Sometimes this job is akin to going down the bookies, only with more despair and no fruit machines. You’re looking for a winner, so you study the lineage, like some dodgy eugenicist. Where have the key personnel been? What promise is buried deep in their DNA? Then you look at current form. What are they doing? How does it compare to the rest of the field? If it all adds up you invest a slab of time and money in the hope they’ll romp home.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/nuala-london-some-beautiful-moments-restaurant-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Will Self: ‘I’m fitter than I’ve ever been’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/will-self-im-fitter-than-ive-ever-been-walking</link>
      <description><p>The novelist, 56, on the health benefits of eating less and walking more</p><p>When I was a child and my parents separated, I went on walking holidays with my dad. My rubric’s always been to walk from home – I’m not a rambler. It’s about a sense of being and place and engagement with the environment around me.</p><p>I like wild swimming, particularly in the sea – I swim out, then float and look at the horizon. I think that’s extremely good for the imagination. I still cycle even though I was knocked off my bike a few years ago, but mostly in the summer – it’s too dangerous in the winter in London.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/will-self-im-fitter-than-ive-ever-been-walking">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Ukip's Gerard Batten reiterates his belief that Islam is a 'death cult'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-gerard-batten-islam-muslims-quran</link>
      <description><p>Interim leader says Muslims should sign a document renouncing parts of the Qur’an</p><p>Ukip’s interim leader, Gerard Batten, has reiterated his belief that Islam is a “death cult” and called for Muslims to be asked to sign a document renouncing parts of the Qur’an, in remarks that risk pushing the beleaguered party even further from the mainstream.</p><p>Batten, an MEP for London, took over as party head on Saturday after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-members-oust-henry-bolton-as-leader-after-five-months">Henry Bolton was removed</a> at an emergency general meeting of party members, called when Bolton refused to step down following controversy about his personal affairs.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-gerard-batten-islam-muslims-quran">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Exclusive: shock figures reveal state of UK’s brutal prisons</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/17/uk-brutal-prisons-failing-violence-drugs-gangs</link>
      <description><p>Observer analysis of inspection reports shows two in five jails are unsafe and inadequate conditions prevail in over two-thirds</p><p>The scale of the crisis engulfing Britain’s prisons can be revealed, after an <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/17/britain-prison-crisis-facing-meltdown-gangs-drugs-violence"><em>Observer </em>investigation</a> found that two-thirds are providing inmates with inadequate conditions or unacceptable treatment.</p><p>An analysis of hundreds of inspections covering 118 institutions found that a staggering 68% are now providing unsatisfactory standards in at least one respect, with two in five jails deemed to be unacceptably unsafe.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/17/uk-brutal-prisons-failing-violence-drugs-gangs">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/botched-cosmetic-surgery-law-change-urged-as-complaints-treble</link>
      <description><p>Celebrity endorsements on social media have led more to seek bargain-price fillers and Botox</p><p>An “alarming” rise in reports of botched cosmetic procedures in the UK has prompted doctors and campaigners to call for better legislation <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/jun/22/protect-children-from-online-cosmetic-surgery-apps-say-campaigners">to protect against </a>rogue practitioners.</p><p>The number of problems related to treatments such as lip fillers and Botox has almost trebled, jumping from 378 in 2016 to 931 in the space of 12 months, according to data from Save Face, a government-approved register of accredited practitioners. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/botched-cosmetic-surgery-law-change-urged-as-complaints-treble">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Teenager stabbed to death in Kensington, London</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/18/teenager-stabbed-to-death-in-kensington-london</link>
      <description><p>Met police investigating whether death of man, 19, was linked to house party</p><p>A teenager has been stabbed to death in west London.</p><p>The 19-year-old was discovered on Logan Place in Kensington at around 3.30am on Sunday.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/neil-kinnock-jeremy-corbyn-labour-stop-brexit-save-nhs</link>
      <description>As 20,000 Labour members protest at party stance on Brexit, former leader adds pressure to resist leaving EU<p>Jeremy Corbyn has come under intense pressure to shift Labour’s position on Brexit after 20,000 members demanded a say over the issue and former leader Neil Kinnock backed halting Britain’s EU exit altogether.</p><p>It is understood that the Labour leader will also be confronted by some in his shadow cabinet this week who want him to back remaining in the single market and customs union.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/neil-kinnock-jeremy-corbyn-labour-stop-brexit-save-nhs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ukip members oust Henry Bolton as leader after only five months</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-members-oust-henry-bolton-as-leader-after-five-months</link>
      <description>Crisis-hit party chooses figure who said Islam is ‘death cult’ as new leader<p>Members of Ukip voted yesterday to sack Henry Bolton, who had been elected only last September as the crisis-hit party’s fourth leader in 18 months. Bolton had been clinging on to the leadership despite a revolt by senior figures after the press reported his relationship with Jo Marney, a model who sent offensive messages about Meghan Markle, the fiancee of Prince Harry.</p><p>Bolton was ousted on Saturday at an emergency meeting where an overwhelming majority of party members endorsed a motion of no confidence in his leadership passed by the party’s ruling national executive committee (NEC). Activists at the meeting in Birmingham <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/ukip-members-vote-to-sack-leader-henry-bolton">voted by 867 to 500</a> in favour of a no-confidence motion on his ability to lead Ukip.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-members-oust-henry-bolton-as-leader-after-five-months">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>MPs’ ‘fake news’ inquiry barred from UK embassy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/mps-fake-news-inquiry-barred-uk-washington-embassy-donald-trump</link>
      <description>Diplomats said ‘offending Trump’ was reason for decision not to host historic session in Washington<p>The British embassy in Washington backtracked on promises to host a session of the parliamentary inquiry into fake news, because of worries it might offend Donald Trump, the <em>Observer</em> has learned.</p><p>Barely a week before MPs from the digital, culture, media and sport committee were due to arrive in Washington for the historic session on 8 February, they were informed in a letter from foreign office minister Alan Duncan that they would have to find a new venue. “We had a report back ... that either the embassy or the UK government felt this would be unhelpful because of the relationship with the US government,” said Ian Lucas, one of the committee members.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/mps-fake-news-inquiry-barred-uk-washington-embassy-donald-trump">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/revealed-us-uk-rightwing-thinktanks-talks-to-ditch-eu-safety-checks</link>
      <description>‘Ideal’ UK-US trade deal would see banned products sold in post-Brexit Britain, says accidentally released memo<p>An unprecedented drive to lobby ministers to ditch strict EU safety standards in order to secure a US trade deal is being drawn up by a transatlantic group of conservative thinktanks, it has emerged.</p><p>Organisers of the self-styled “shadow trade talks”, which are set to include 10 leading rightwing and libertarian groups from the UK and the US, are preparing to push their “ideal free trade agreement” that would allow the import of US meats, drugs and chemicals banned in Britain.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/revealed-us-uk-rightwing-thinktanks-talks-to-ditch-eu-safety-checks">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Amid the chaos of Syria, will Israel and Iran launch an all-out war?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/amid-chaos-syria-will-israel-iran-launch-all-out-war</link>
      <description>Neither country will benefit from a new Middle East conflict, but unless they cease military clashes, such as those inside Syria last weekend, hopes of peace remain fragile<p>Tensions between Israel and Iran have hit a new high following last weekend’s unprecedented <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/10/israeli-fighter-jet-shot-down-by-syrian-fire-says-military" title="">military clashes inside Syria</a>. The fighting has intensified fears that the Middle East is heading for all-out war. But such alarming predictions assume both protagonists standing toe-to-toe, actuallywant to fight. Is this reallytrue?</p><p>Iran is portrayed as a wanton aggressor, especially by the Trump administration and the Saudis. It has steadily expanded its military presence in Syria since supporting Bashar al-Assad after 2011, deploying Afghan and Pakistani Shia militias, Lebanese Hezbollah fighters and its own Revolutionary Guards.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/amid-chaos-syria-will-israel-iran-launch-all-out-war">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/nigeria-releases-475-boko-haram-suspects-for-rehabilitation</link>
      <description><p>Authorities said some suspected of links with militants had been held without trial since 2010<br></p><p>A Nigerian court has released 475 people allegedly affiliated with Boko Haram for rehabilitation, the justice ministry said, as the country’s biggest legal investigation of the militant Islamist insurgency continued.</p><p> The first person convicted for the kidnapping in 2014 of Chibok schoolgirls, sentenced to 15 years’ imprisonment last week, was also handed an additional 15-year sentence, to run back-to-back, the ministry said in a statement.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/nigeria-releases-475-boko-haram-suspects-for-rehabilitation">Continue reading...</a></description>
